message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is most likely lactose intolerant, and lactose intolerance causes an increased osmotic gap in the stool due to unabsorbed lactose. The urinary D-xylose concentration would not be affected by lactose intolerance. Decreased fecal fat content and decreased breath hydrogen content are not features of lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, and when lactose is administered orally, there is an osmotic gap present in the stool due to unabsorbed lactose. The other options are not associated with lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely to have lactose intolerance, which causes an increase in the stool osmotic gap. Lactose intolerance does not affect D-xylose, fecal fat content or breath hydrogen content.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely has lactose intolerance, as her symptoms occur following ingestion of lactose-containing foods. Administration of lactose will result in an increased osmotic gap in the stool, as the lactose is not properly absorbed and draws water into the colon. The other options are not related to lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and trigger foods suggest lactose intolerance. Administration of lactose orally will cause an osmotic gap in the stool, indicating malabsorption of lactose. Urinary D-xylose concentration is used to measure small bowel absorption, which is not affected in lactose intolerance. Fecal fat content is used to diagnose fat malabsorption, and breath hydrogen content is used to measure lactose fermentation in the colon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely to have lactose intolerance, and administration of lactose orally may lead to an increased osmotic gap in the stool due to unabsorbed lactose. Decreased urinary D-xylose concentration suggests malabsorption of carbohydrates, decreased fecal fat content suggests malabsorption of fat, and increased breath hydrogen content may occur in lactose intolerance due to fermentation of unabsorbed lactose by gut bacteria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, and a lactose tolerance test can confirm the diagnosis. Increased stool osmotic gap is the most likely change to be observed in this patient, as lactose is not absorbed in the small intestine and increases osmotic pressure in the colon. Decreased urinary D-xylose concentration, decreased fecal fat content, and decreased breath hydrogen content are not expected changes in lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lactose intolerance. Increased stool osmotic gap is a common finding in lactose intolerance because lactose is osmotically active and draws water into the bowel lumen. Decreased urinary D-xylose concentration, decreased fecal fat content, and decreased breath hydrogen content are not associated with lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, and administration of lactose orally can confirm the diagnosis. Increased stool osmotic gap is a characteristic finding in lactose intolerance due to the incomplete absorption of lactose. The other options are not related to lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of lactose intolerance, and administering lactose will confirm the diagnosis. Increased stool osmotic gap is expected in lactose intolerance due to the osmotic effect of unabsorbed lactose in the colon. Urinary D-xylose concentration is not expected to be affected. Fecal fat content may be decreased in malabsorption syndromes but is not specific to lactose intolerance. Increased breath hydrogen content is also expected in lactose intolerance due to the fermentation of lactose by colonic bacteria producing hydrogen gas that is absorbed and exhaled.
